1:
See, my eye has seen all this;\q my ear has heard and understood it.
\q
2:
What you know, the same I also know;\q I am not inferior to you.


\q
3:
However, I would rather speak with the Almighty;\q I wish to reason with God.
\q
4:
But you whitewash the truth with lies;\q you are all physicians of no value.
\q
5:
Oh, that you would altogether hold your peace!\q That would be your wisdom.


\q
6:
Hear now my own reasoning;\q listen to the pleading of my own lips.
\q
7:
Will you speak unrighteously for God,\q and will you talk deceitfully for him?
\q
8:
Would you really show kindness to him?\q Would you really argue in court as attorneys for God?


\q
9:
Would it really be good for you when he searches you out? \q Could you deceive him as you might deceive men?
\q
10:
He would surely reprove you\q if in secret you showed partiality.

\q
11:
Would not his majesty make you afraid?\q Would not his dread fall upon you?
\q
12:
Your memorable sayings are proverbs made of ashes;\q your defenses are defenses made of clay.


\q
13:
Hold your peace, let me alone, so that I may speak,\q let come what may on me.
\q
14:
I will take my own flesh in my teeth;\q I will take my life in my hands.
\q
15:
See, if he kills me, I will have no hope left;\q nevertheless, I will defend my ways before him.


\q
16:
This will be the reason for my deliverance,\q for no godless person would come before him.
\q
17:
God, listen carefully to my speech;\q let my declaration come to your ears.


\q
18:
See now, I have set my defense in order;\q I know that I am innocent.
\q
19:
Who is the one who would argue against me in court?\q If you came to do so, and if I were proved wrong, then I would be silent and give up my life.


\q
20:
God, do only two things for me,\q and then I will not hide myself from your face:
\q
21:
withdraw your oppressive hand from me,\q and do not let your terrors make me afraid.
\q
22:
Then call me, and I will answer;\q or let me speak to you, and you answer me.


\q
23:
How many are my iniquities and sins?\q Let me know my transgression and my sin.
\q
24:
Why do you hide your face from me\q and treat me like your enemy?
\q
25:
Will you persecute a driven leaf?\q Will you pursue dry stubble?


\q
26:
For you write down bitter things against me;\q you make me inherit the iniquities of my youth.
\q
28: although I am like a rotten thing that wastes away,\q like a garment that moths have eaten.
